p: Our results ( Fig 3 / Table 3) show that the effectiveness of interventions, which conceptually map onto changes in sub-processes, depend greatly on how the underlying propagation process is decomposed; even with composite rate of propagation (Î») constant, one single intervention can have effects that differ two orders of magnitude depending on the values for Radiation, Transmission and Reception (see Fig 4 / Table 4), and that intervention effectiveness can differ roughly by a factor eight from the traditional single parameter models in extreme settings. The findings indicate that without decomposition of the mechanism of propagation, substantial over- or underestimation of intervention effectiveness can occur.
